summary_en: The paragraph uses 1 Cor 2:6 (“among the perfect/mature”) to argue that Paul’s gospel has a distinctly theological, cognitive character for all believers, even though he does articulate a deeper “wisdom” for the mature. Terms like gnosis/epignosis can denote advanced understanding for the mature, yet they also describe the common knowledge of the gospel. Paul teaches with ordered method and views the gospel as objective truth requiring enlightened understanding; this unified knowledge centers on God and Christ. Thus, 1 Cor 2:6 does not imply an esoteric, separate theology for an elite, but a deeper level within the same coherent system.

summary_en: The author explains that 1 Corinthians 15:35 raises a question about the kind or mode of the resurrection body rather than its material substance. Paul’s sowing metaphor teaches that our inability to picture the resurrection body does not make it impossible; God gives a body as He wills, often quite unlike the seed. The passage should not be pressed to assert a material ‘germ’ in the corpse or to detail degrees of identity; what is sown is the body, which dies and is made alive. The focus is on the body, not the believer’s subjective spirit. “Sowing” can be viewed as encompassing the whole earthly life (including burial). Paul also answers the 15:35 question by pointing to the diversity of bodies God already uses (15:39–41): here ‘sarx’ means ‘body,’ and the resurrection body will differ in kind (heteros) from the present body, not merely as another of the same kind (allos).

summary_en: Paul uses Genesis 2:7 to ground the contrast in 1 Cor 15:45 between the first Adam as a “living soul” (psychical body) and the last Adam as “life‑giving Spirit” (pneumatic body). The psychical body, given at creation, is animated by the natural soul—adequate for earthly life but vulnerable to death once sin enters; corruption and weakness are not inherent necessities of creation itself. Paul avoids calling the creation body “fleshly” (sarkikos) because that term is tied to sin. He argues typologically: the creation-body prefigures a higher, resurrection body, so if a psychical body exists, a pneumatic body also exists. He rejects Philo’s two‑creation scheme and does not teach a change of bodily substance; “from heaven” does not denote material. Positively, the believer’s resurrection body will bear Christ’s image.

summary_en: Both excerpts treat Paul’s contrast between the first man (Adam) and the second man (Christ) to clarify what “of/from heaven” means. The first man is “of the earth” in the order of creation and, once sin enters, his psychical (natural) body is subject to corruption; the second man is “of heaven,” indicating a heavenly origin/sphere and mode, not a different material substance. Paul avoids sarkikos (fleshly) because it is tied to sin, and he does not claim the resurrection body is made of “spirit” as a substance. Genesis 2:7 undergirds a typological argument: the first creation-body prefigures the higher, pneumatic resurrection body realized in Christ, whose image believers will bear. “From heaven” also denotes God’s supernatural activity and the heavenly pattern to which realities conform, not merely a reverent circumlocution for God.

chapter: The paragraph treats 1 Cor 15:51-53 as a key text on the transformation at the Parousia, restricted to believers. It contrasts Paul’s metaphors: in 2 Cor 5 the heavenly body is "put on" over the earthly (mortal swallowed up by life), while in 1 Cor 15 the old body is changed into the new. Two readings of 1 Cor 15:51-53 are noted: (1) it generally describes the transformation applicable to both the resurrected dead and those still alive, supporting continuity between present and resurrection bodies; (2) Paul expected all his readers to survive and be changed alive. The author judges more plausible the reading that "not all" will die, but all—both dead and surviving—will be changed at the Parousia, acknowledging textual/interpretive difficulties reflected in early variant readings.
